title: Watercolor Properties
description: Transparent, unpredictable, and luminous â€” understanding how water behaves.

hook.text: Watercolor is the most transparent painting medium â€” light passes through the paint and bounces off the white paper beneath, creating a luminous glow that no other medium can match. But water has a mind of its own.

buildup.text: Key properties: transparency (light shines through layers), granulation (pigment settles into paper texture), flow (water carries pigment in unpredictable ways), and permanence (once dry, hard to change â€” you can't paint light over dark).

discovery.text: Watercolor works BACKWARDS compared to oil/acrylic: you preserve lights (the white paper) and build up darks. The lightest value in a watercolor is unpainted paper. This means planning your lights BEFORE starting.

twist.text: Watercolor's 'happy accidents' â€” blooms, runs, unexpected blending â€” are features, not bugs. The best watercolorists work WITH the medium's unpredictability, embracing what the water does and incorporating it into the painting.

climax.text: Wet a piece of watercolor paper and drop different colors onto it. Watch them bloom, mix, and flow. Then let it dry. The result will have effects you couldn't have planned â€” and that's watercolor's magic.

punchline.text: Watercolor isn't painted â€” it's guided. You make suggestions; the water decides.

quiz.question: Why must watercolor painters plan their lightest areas before starting?
options: The lightest value is unpainted white paper â€” once paint covers an area, you can't go lighter
